Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This three year REU Site program at Syracuse University will engage undergraduate students in research focused in the area of interactive biomaterials. The objectives of this REU Site program are to: (1) train students in leading edge research techniques through independent biomaterials research projects in a multidisciplinary, collaborative, and open laboratory environment; (2) to provide multifaceted mentoring opportunities and network building experiences that ultimately increase the likelihood that participants will pursue graduate education in their chosen discipline; and (3) to train students to be effective communicators of their research to their peers and the scientific community. These goals will be accomplished through participation in independent, interactive biomaterials research projects in faculty laboratories, one-on-one mentoring from faculty advisors and graduate student coaches, an innovative career mentoring program, interactive laboratory tours with REU student-led demonstrations, student research presentations, team building activities, and social events. This program aims to engage undergraduate students in meaningful and stimulating research, educational and social experiences as a means of increasing their enthusiasm and preparation for future graduate level study and careers in biomaterials science and engineering.

The research projects available to students in the REU program will advance fundamental scientific knowledge in the areas of shape memory polymers, stimulus-responsive polymers, drug delivery, control of bacterial biofilms, cell-biomaterial interactions, electrochemistry of metallic biomaterials, tissue engineering, and molecular modeling of interactive biomaterials.

The REU Site program will broaden the participation of students from institutions with limited research opportunities, women, and underrepresented minorities in meaningful undergraduate research, strengthened by the Hampton Roads HBCU Cluster Partnership. A signature element of the proposed REU site is a career mentoring initiative, focused on both industrial and academic career paths at the PhD level, which emphasizes the importance and benefits of graduate education in STEM disciplines. The best practices of this REU site will be broadly disseminated via the web and educational publications, with an aim to produce models for replication at future REU sites.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2012-14, Syracuse University welcomed cohorts of twelve students per year to the Syracuse Biomaterials Institute (SBI) for the Interactive Biomaterials REU Site. We were very successful in recruiting a diverse pool of candidates, with respect to gender, race and ethnicity, undergraduate major, type of undergraduate institution, and geography. We brought these students together for ten weeks each summer in order to achieve the following educational objectives: 1) to train students in leading edge research techniques through independent biomaterials research projects in a multidisciplinary, collaborative, and open laboratory environment; 2) to provide multi-faceted mentoring opportunities and network building experiences that ultimately increase the likelihood that participants will pursue graduate education in their chosen discipline; and 3) to train students to be effective communicators of their research to their peers and the scientific community.

In our program, REU students were individually matched to specific faculty laboratories at the time of acceptance into the program, based on their undergraduate major, research interests expressed in an essay, previous experience, and recommendations. Faculty mentors contacted their students to provide a brief introduction to their laboratory and the research project, including relevant references to review prior to the start of the REU. In addition to having a faculty mentor, each REU student had a graduate student or post-doctoral associate assigned to him or her as a graduate mentor. These graduate mentors were involved with hands on training in laboratory techniques and actively supported the REU students to help them become increasingly independent in the laboratory. Such mentoring relationships not only helped the REU students in their daily research efforts, but also provided a first-hand glimpse into the life of a graduate student. We have learned that graduate student mentors are a valuable resource to REU students who are interested in learning more about the process of applying to and selecting a graduate program. The mentors provide a realistic view of the graduate school experience and can, more than the faculty, relate to REU students on a peer level.

In addition to research, REU students participated in a number of educational, career development, and cohort-building social activities each summer.  Some highlights included: a three-part career mentoring series on planning for graduate school, the industrial PhD experience, and the academic PhD experience; team building at the Syracuse University Outdoor Education Center and Challenge Course; a week-long lecture series designed to immerse students in the theme of Interactive Biomaterials; and multiple opportunities for students to present their research.  REU students were also housed together in a dormitory on the SU campus each summer, along with participants in other REU programs and summer research initiatives on campus. This residential plan has proven tremendously successful in promoting the development of strong peer networks, both within and across the cohorts of undergraduate researchers on our campus. 

We consistently achieved all three educational objectives of our REU site with each cohort.  All REU students reported that they made either moderate or great gains in learning research techniques, especially techniques specific to their projects. Most participants (75%) reported that they were more likely to apply to graduate school as a result of the REU. All participants reported that they had made moderate or great gains in their poster preparation and oral presentation skills as a result of the REU. In addition to these results, we found that nearly all participants (92%) affirmed that their interest in biomaterials research/careers had increased greatly or moderately as a result of the REU experience and a majority of participants (72%) reported that they were more likely to pursue a career in biomaterials as a result of the REU experience.

The concept of Interactive Biomaterials is hardly limited to the interface between materials and the biological environment. Fostering educational and social interactions amongst students within the REU cohort, between REU students and their faculty and graduate student mentors, and between REU students and the greater scientific community has been a significant aspect of this program. Our program outcomes clearly demonstrate that the REU does in fact provide meaningful mentoring and network building opportunities of this nature.
